lines.text: The mind knows no limits when used properly. Think of a pentagram, Donald. Now put another inside, a third, and a fourth. No pencil is sharp enough to draw as fine as you can think, and no paper large enough to hold your imagination. In fact, it is only in the mind that we can conceive infinity.
[the infinite progression of pentagrams turns into a hallway of doors]
Mathematical thinking has opened the doors to the exciting adventures of science.
I'll be doggone! I've never seen so many doors before.
[Runs back and forth from one door to another]
Each discovery leads to many others. An endless chain.
Hey, hey! What's the matter with these doors? Hey! These doors won't open! They're locked!
Of course they are locked. These are the doors of the future, and the key is...
Mathematics!

Right. Mathematics. The boundless treasures of science are locked behind those doors. In time, they will be opened by the curious and inquiring minds of future generations. In the words of Galileo, "Mathematics is the alphabet with which God has written the universe."
And now you are ready for the most exciting game of all.
Oh, boy!
And the playing field for this game is in the mind.
[Fade in to Donald's mind, revealing a disorganized room with dusty file cabinets]
antiquated ideas! Bungling! False concepts! Superstitions! Confusion! To think straight, we'll have to clean house.
[the cabinets close and a broom starts sweeping by itself; Donald's face contorts as dust and moths fly out of his head]
There, that's more like it. A nice clean sweep.

[calling out]
Hello!
Hello Donald.
That's me! Where am I?
Mathmagic Land.
Mathmagic Land? Never heard of it.
It's the land of great adventure.
Well, who are you?
I'm a spirit. The True Spirit of Adventure.
That's for me! What's next?
A journey through the wonderlands of Mathematics.
Mathematics! That's for eggheads!
Eggheads? Now hold on Donald. You like music, don't you?
Yeah.
Well, without *eggheads*, there would be no music.
Pi is equal to three point one four one five, *nine* two six five three five eight nine seven four seven, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera!

[shaking hands with Pythagoras]
Pythag, old boy, put 'er there!
[Pythagoras disappears, leaving the pentagram on Donald's hand]
Well, I'll be a pi-squared egghead!
[laughs]
Gee, Mister Spirit. There's a lot more to mathematics than two-times-two.
[as the Pytagoreans play music]
What's going on?
Shh, it's a jam session.
Gimme something with a beat.
Shh!
[Donald plays a urn like a bongo drum; the Pytagoreans play along]
[Donald winds up on a giant chessboard and his sailor-suit attire has somehow changed to that of Alice from "Alice In Wonderland" and he meets up red king and queen chess pieces]

[about Donald]
Good heavens! What's this?
Upon my soul, it appears to be a lost pawn!
I'm no pawn, I'm Donald Duck!
He says he's Donald Duck.
Preposterous!
Or he could be an Alice.

[angrily]
Alice?
No, no, no, it's a lost pawn.

[prodding Donald]
Lost pawn?
[Donald runs off]
Stop that pawn!
Help! Mr. Spirit! Help, help, help!
[the chess pieces chase Donald off the chess board]

[referring to a ballerina being measured with the golden rectangles]
Well, well, well. This is mathematics? I gotta have me some of that!
[he runs up to the model and breaks the rectangles apart]
Ah-ah-ah, Donald!
Let me try it!
[he picks up a small rectangle]
No, no, no!
Ideal proportions.
Not quite.
[Donald tosses away the rectangle and picks up a larger one]
Uh-uh. No, I'm afraid not.
[Donald tries to fit himself inside the rectangle]
Well, we can't all be mathematically perfect.
Oh, yeah?
[Donald squeezes himself into the rectangle, and he successfully gets inside taking up the shape of a pentagon]
There, I knew I could do it!
Now that you're all bent up in a pentagon, let's see how nature uses the same mathematical form.
[various forms in nature with this shape are shown]

The petunia, the star jasmine, the starfish, the wax flower. There are literally thousands of members in good standing. In nature, it's the Pythagorean idea of the star. All nature's works have a mathematical logic, and her patterns are limitless.
[first lines]

[entering Mathemagic Land]
Mighty strange.

[while playing billiards, on hitting the other two balls the right way]
Hey! It works! Oh, boy! It's a cinch.
[but he now struggles to work out the diamond system]
If I hit it here... 3.5 plus 4 to 4.5 minus 3... divided by that...
You're making it tough for yourself Donald.
[He hits it wildly and the cue ball bounces off numerous cushions before hitting the other two balls]
How do you like that for mathematics, Mr. Spirit?
Wonderful, Donald.

"Everything is arranged according to number and mathematical shapes." Yes, there's mathematics in music, in art, in just about everything. And as the Greeks have guessed, the rules are always the same.
